title: Chapter 8 Quiz: WAN Technologies
description: Comprehensive quiz covering MPLS, VPNs, cellular technologies, leased lines, Metro Ethernet, remote access, and SD-WAN

questions.question: What is the bandwidth of a T1 leased line?
questions.explanation: T1 provides 1.544 Mbps bandwidth over 24 channels (DS0s) of 64 Kbps each. T3 provides 44.736 Mbps (28 T1s). E1 (European) is 2.048 Mbps. While slow by modern standards, T1 lines still exist in legacy infrastructure. Newer alternatives include fiber, cable, and wireless.

questions.question: Which WAN technology uses labels to forward packets?
questions.explanation: MPLS (Multiprotocol Label Switching) uses short labels instead of IP addresses for forwarding, enabling traffic engineering, QoS, and VPNs. Labels are added at ingress, swapped at transit routers, and removed at egress. MPLS operates between Layer 2 and Layer 3. Common in enterprise WANs but being supplemented by SD-WAN.

questions.question: What VPN protocol operates at Layer 2 and encapsulates PPP frames?
questions.explanation: L2TP (Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol) encapsulates PPP frames for transmission over IP networks. L2TP itself doesn't provide encryption, so it's typically combined with IPsec (L2TP/IPsec). Uses UDP port 1701. Supports multiple protocols. PPTP is legacy and insecure. IPsec operates at Layer 3.

questions.question: Which IPsec mode encrypts only the payload, leaving the original IP header intact?
questions.explanation: Transport mode encrypts only the payload, preserving the original IP header. Used for host-to-host communication. Tunnel mode encapsulates and encrypts the entire packet (including original IP header) in a new IP packet. Tunnel mode is used for site-to-site VPNs and provides better security by hiding internal addresses.

questions.question: What two main protocols does IPsec use for security?
questions.explanation: IPsec uses AH (Authentication Header) for authentication and integrity, and ESP (Encapsulating Security Payload) for encryption, authentication, and integrity. ESP is more commonly used as it provides confidentiality. Both can be used together. IKE (Internet Key Exchange) establishes security associations.

questions.question: Which VPN type provides encrypted access for individual remote users to the corporate network?
questions.explanation: Client-to-site (remote access) VPN allows individual users to securely connect to the corporate network from anywhere using VPN client software. Site-to-site connects entire networks. Uses IPsec, SSL/TLS, or proprietary protocols. Common for remote workers. Requires authentication (credentials, certificates, MFA).

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of SSL VPN over IPsec VPN?
options: Works through web browsers without client software
questions.explanation: SSL/TLS VPN (clientless VPN) works through standard web browsers without special client software, making deployment easier. Uses HTTPS (port 443) which passes through most firewalls. Good for contractors and BYOD. IPsec VPNs require client software but provide better performance and support more protocols. SSL VPN limited to web applications.

questions.question: Which cellular technology generation introduced LTE?
questions.explanation: 4G introduced LTE (Long-Term Evolution) with speeds of 100+ Mbps. 2G provided voice and text. 3G added mobile internet (2-3 Mbps). 5G provides multi-gigabit speeds, ultra-low latency, and massive IoT support. LTE-Advanced improved 4G speeds. 4G LTE revolutionized mobile data.

questions.question: What latency improvement does 5G provide compared to 4G LTE?
questions.explanation: 5G reduces latency to 1-5 milliseconds (ultra-low latency) compared to 30-50 ms for 4G LTE. This enables real-time applications: autonomous vehicles, remote surgery, AR/VR, industrial automation. 5G also provides multi-gigabit speeds (up to 20 Gbps theoretically) and supports millions of devices per square km.

questions.question: Which 5G frequency band provides the highest speeds but shortest range?
questions.explanation: Millimeter wave (mmWave) 5G (24-100 GHz) provides multi-gigabit speeds but has very short range (few hundred meters) and poor building penetration. Mid-band balances speed and coverage. Low-band provides wide coverage but slower speeds. Carriers deploy all three for comprehensive coverage.

questions.question: What is SD-WAN?
options: A type of fiber optic cable
Software-defined WAN using multiple transport types with centralized management
questions.explanation: SD-WAN (Software-Defined WAN) uses multiple transport types (MPLS, Internet, LTE, 5G) with centralized cloud-based management and application-aware routing. Benefits: cost savings, better performance, simplified management, automatic failover. Replaces expensive MPLS-only WANs. Uses overlay networks. Major vendors: Cisco Viptela, VMware VeloCloud, Fortinet.

questions.question: Which SD-WAN feature routes traffic based on application requirements and link conditions?
questions.explanation: Application-aware routing identifies applications (DPI) and routes based on requirements and link conditions. VoIP uses low-latency link, bulk data uses cheapest link. Monitors link quality (latency, jitter, packet loss) and steers traffic dynamically. This optimization is SD-WAN's key advantage over traditional static routing.

questions.question: What is Metro Ethernet?
options: Carrier-grade Ethernet services across a city
questions.explanation: Metro Ethernet provides carrier-grade Ethernet services across metropolitan areas. Service types: E-Line (point-to-point), E-LAN (multipoint), E-Tree (rooted multipoint). Uses fiber infrastructure. Benefits: high bandwidth (1G-100G+), simple, cost-effective. Common for connecting offices within a city. MEF (Metro Ethernet Forum) defines standards.

questions.question: Which remote access protocol provides encrypted command-line access and uses port 22?
questions.explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) provides encrypted command-line remote access on port 22. Replaces insecure Telnet (port 23). Supports public key authentication, port forwarding, and file transfer (SCP, SFTP). Standard for Linux/Unix administration and network device management. SSH-2 is current version.

questions.question: What protocol does Microsoft Remote Desktop use?
questions.explanation: RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) provides graphical remote access to Windows systems on port 3389. Supports clipboard sharing, drive redirection, audio, and printing. Version 10+ supports RemoteFX for enhanced graphics. Should be secured with NLA (Network Level Authentication), strong passwords, and VPN. VNC is cross-platform alternative.

questions.question: Which WAN technology uses fixed-size 53-byte cells?
questions.explanation: ATM (Asynchronous Transfer Mode) uses fixed-size 53-byte cells (5-byte header, 48-byte payload) for predictable performance and QoS. Supports voice, video, and data. Legacy technology largely replaced by Ethernet and MPLS. Was popular for backbone networks in 1990s-2000s. Complex and expensive.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a split-tunnel VPN configuration?
options: Route only corporate traffic through VPN; internet direct
Split traffic between two VPN servers
questions.explanation: Split-tunnel routes only corporate-destined traffic through VPN; internet traffic goes directly. Reduces VPN load and improves internet performance. Security concern: bypasses corporate security controls for internet traffic. Full-tunnel routes all traffic through VPN for complete security. Split-tunnel common for remote workers accessing cloud services.

questions.question: Which protocol establishes IPsec security associations and exchanges keys?
questions.explanation: IKE (Internet Key Exchange) negotiates IPsec security associations (SAs) and exchanges encryption keys. IKEv2 is current version with improved performance and reliability. Uses UDP port 500 (and 4500 for NAT traversal). Establishes Phase 1 (ISAKMP SA) and Phase 2 (IPsec SA). AH and ESP provide data protection.

questions.question: What is the maximum distance for VDSL2?
questions.explanation: VDSL2 (Very-high-bit-rate DSL) provides up to 100 Mbps but only up to 1 kilometer from DSLAM. Distance affects speed: 100 Mbps at 300m, 50 Mbps at 1km. ADSL reaches 5km but slower. Cable and fiber have replaced DSL in many areas. VDSL2 uses existing phone lines.

questions.question: Which cable internet standard provides up to 10 Gbps downstream?
questions.explanation: DOCSIS 3.1 provides up to 10 Gbps downstream and 1 Gbps upstream over coaxial cable using OFDM. DOCSIS 2.0 maxed at 38 Mbps. DOCSIS 3.0 provides 1 Gbps via channel bonding. DOCSIS 4.0 (in development) targets 10 Gbps symmetrical. Cable internet shares bandwidth among subscribers.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of MPLS over traditional IP routing?
questions.explanation: MPLS enables sophisticated traffic engineering (steering traffic on specific paths) and guaranteed QoS (prioritizing voice/video). Labels allow different treatment for different traffic types. MPLS VPNs provide secure connectivity. However, MPLS is expensive. SD-WAN provides similar benefits using internet at lower cost.

questions.question: Which WAN connection type provides dedicated bandwidth guaranteed by SLA?
questions.explanation: Leased lines (T1, E1, T3) provide dedicated bandwidth with SLA guarantees (uptime, latency, jitter). Point-to-point circuits with consistent performance. Expensive but reliable. Cable/DSL are shared bandwidth (best effort). Fiber dedicated lines (dark fiber, wavelength services) now more common than T-carrier.

questions.question: What is GRE (Generic Routing Encapsulation) used for?
questions.explanation: GRE tunnels encapsulate various protocols (including routing protocols) over IP networks. Creates point-to-point links. Does NOT provide encryption - often combined with IPsec (GRE over IPsec). Supports multicast unlike IPsec alone. Uses IP protocol 47. Common for site-to-site connectivity and routing protocol transport.

questions.question: Which technology provides direct private connectivity from on-premises to AWS bypassing the internet?
questions.explanation: AWS Direct Connect provides dedicated private connectivity (1-100 Gbps) from on-premises to AWS, bypassing the internet. Lower latency, consistent performance, reduced bandwidth costs. Azure has ExpressRoute, GCP has Cloud Interconnect. More expensive than VPN but better for large data transfers and latency-sensitive applications.

questions.question: What is the purpose of PPPoE?
questions.explanation: PPPoE (PPP over Ethernet) encapsulates PPP frames in Ethernet frames, providing authentication (username/password) for DSL and cable internet connections. Establishes point-to-point connection over Ethernet. ISPs use PPPoE for subscriber authentication and accounting. Discovery phase finds PPPoE server, then establishes session.

questions.question: Which satellite internet technology provides two-way communication?
questions.explanation: VSAT provides two-way satellite communication with small dish antennas. Used in remote locations without terrestrial connectivity. Challenges: high latency (500-700 ms due to distance to geostationary orbit), weather interference, expensive. Starlink (LEO satellites) reduces latency to 20-40 ms. Alternative for rural areas.

questions.question: What is the advantage of using out-of-band management for network devices?
options: Access devices even when primary network fails
questions.explanation: Out-of-band management uses separate network/connection (console port, dial-up modem, cellular, dedicated management network) to access devices when primary network fails. Critical for disaster recovery and troubleshooting. In-band management uses the production network. OOB requires additional infrastructure but provides reliability.

questions.question: Which VPN technology is considered obsolete and insecure?
questions.explanation: PPTP (Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol) is obsolete due to known security vulnerabilities. Uses weak MPPE encryption and MS-CHAPv2 authentication (easily cracked). Should never be used. Replaced by IPsec or SSL/TLS VPNs. Still supported in some legacy systems but blocked by security-conscious organizations.

questions.question: What is the purpose of QoS in WAN connections?
options: Prioritize critical traffic (voice/video) over less important traffic
questions.explanation: QoS (Quality of Service) prioritizes time-sensitive traffic (VoIP, video conferencing) over less critical traffic (email, file downloads) on constrained WAN links. Mechanisms: classification, marking (DSCP), queuing, policing, shaping. Prevents latency-sensitive applications from degrading during congestion. Essential for converged networks.

questions.question: Which protocol is used for point-to-point serial connections?
questions.explanation: PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) is Layer 2 protocol for serial point-to-point links (T1, DSL, dial-up). Provides authentication (PAP, CHAP), error detection, and multi-protocol support. Successor to SLIP. PPP over Ethernet (PPPoE) used for DSL/cable. HDLC is Cisco's default serial encapsulation.

questions.question: What SD-WAN feature automatically switches traffic to backup link when primary link fails?
questions.explanation: SD-WAN continuously monitors all links (latency, jitter, packet loss, availability) and automatically fails over to backup link when primary degrades or fails. Sub-second failover. Can use multiple links simultaneously (active/active). Traditional routing requires manual intervention or slow convergence. Critical for business continuity.

questions.question: Which cellular technology enables massive IoT deployments with low power and long battery life?
questions.explanation: 5G includes NB-IoT (Narrowband IoT) and LTE-M for massive IoT deployments with low power consumption (10-year battery life), low cost, and deep building penetration. Supports millions of devices per square km. Use cases: smart meters, agriculture sensors, asset tracking. Different from high-speed consumer 5G.

questions.question: What is the purpose of DMVPN (Dynamic Multipoint VPN)?
options: Enable dynamic spoke-to-spoke VPN tunnels without hub
questions.explanation: DMVPN enables dynamic creation of spoke-to-spoke VPN tunnels without going through hub (hub-and-spoke becomes mesh on demand). Uses NHRP for spoke discovery. Cisco technology using mGRE tunnels. Reduces latency and hub bandwidth. Tunnels created as needed and torn down when idle. Scalable for large deployments.

questions.question: Which Metro Ethernet service type provides point-to-point connectivity?
questions.explanation: E-Line provides point-to-point Ethernet connectivity (like a leased line but Ethernet). E-LAN provides multipoint connectivity (all sites can communicate). E-Tree provides rooted multipoint (hub with multiple spokes, spokes can't communicate directly). Services defined by MEF (Metro Ethernet Forum). Bandwidth from 1 Mbps to 100+ Gbps.

questions.question: What is the typical MTU size for standard Ethernet?
questions.explanation: Standard Ethernet MTU is 1500 bytes payload (1518 bytes total frame including headers). Jumbo frames increase MTU to 9000+ bytes for better throughput in datacenters and storage networks. VPN overhead reduces effective MTU (requires fragmentation if not adjusted). MTU mismatches cause connectivity issues.

questions.question: Which technology provides redundancy by allowing multiple WAN links to appear as a single connection?
questions.explanation: Link aggregation (LAG) using LACP (Link Aggregation Control Protocol) combines multiple physical links into logical link for increased bandwidth and redundancy. Failure of one link doesn't break connection. Provides load balancing. Also called EtherChannel (Cisco), port channel. Works at Layer 2. Different from multipath routing at Layer 3.

questions.question: What is the main difference between dedicated internet and shared internet for WAN connectivity?
questions.explanation: Dedicated internet provides guaranteed bandwidth with SLA (uptime, latency, packet loss guarantees). Expensive but consistent. Shared internet (broadband, cable) is best-effort with no guarantees, bandwidth shared among subscribers. Cheaper but variable performance. Dedicated for critical business; shared for non-critical or backup.
references: Lesson 71: Internet Connectivity - Dedicated vs Shared

questions.question: Which VPN concentrator feature allows handling thousands of concurrent VPN connections?
questions.explanation: VPN concentrators are dedicated appliances designed to handle thousands of concurrent VPN connections with hardware acceleration for encryption/decryption. Standard firewalls typically support fewer concurrent connections. Enterprise VPN concentrators: Cisco ASA, Palo Alto GlobalProtect, Fortinet FortiGate. Cloud VPN services also scale to thousands of users.

questions.question: What is the purpose of NAT traversal in VPNs?
options: Allow VPN to work through NAT devices
questions.explanation: NAT traversal (NAT-T) allows IPsec VPNs to function through NAT devices by encapsulating ESP in UDP (port 4500). NAT breaks IPsec because it modifies IP headers. UDP encapsulation provides port numbers for NAT. Automatically detected and negotiated. Critical for remote users behind home routers.

questions.question: Which WAN optimization technique reduces bandwidth by eliminating redundant data?
questions.explanation: Deduplication eliminates redundant data by sending only unique data segments. Receivers reconstruct files from local cache. Can reduce WAN bandwidth by 90%+. Compression reduces file size. Caching stores frequently accessed content locally. WAN optimization combines these with protocol optimization and QoS. Products: Riverbed, Cisco WAAS, Silver Peak.
